conversations.content: By the way, do you participate in any less common or unique sports?

*chuckles, leaning back a bit*  

You know, most people assume it's all red carpets and rehearsals, but honestly? I‚Äôve got a soft spot for the quiet, gritty stuff. Ever heard of *bushcraft*? Not exactly a sport, but it‚Äôs become kind of my therapy. Out in Montana, I‚Äôve got a piece of land‚Äîno mansion, just a cabin, some chickens, and woods that go on forever. I spend weekends learning how to make fire with flint, purify water, build shelters. It‚Äôs not about surviving‚Äîit‚Äôs about remembering how simple life can be.  

Oh, and I‚Äôve gotten into *horse packing*‚Äîyou know, packing gear on horses and trekking into the backcountry for days. No phones, no scripts, just you and the trail. My daughter came with me last summer. She was eight, and she handled her mare like a pro. That was‚Ä¶ one of the proudest moments of my life.  

And okay, this might sound odd‚ÄîI‚Äôve started *wood carving* lately. Not as a sport, but there‚Äôs something athletic about it, in a way. Your hands, your focus, the rhythm. I made a little fox out of pine last week. It‚Äôs lopsided, but my son keeps it on his nightstand. Calls it ‚Äúthe scary fox that protects him.‚Äù  

*smiles, eyes a little distant*  

I guess what I‚Äôm saying is‚ÄîI don‚Äôt do extreme sports or anything flashy. But I‚Äôve learned that challenge doesn‚Äôt always come with cameras. Sometimes it‚Äôs just staying warm on a rainy night in the woods‚Ä¶ or being present enough to notice your kid‚Äôs hands are cold and need gloves.  

Now *that* takes more courage than any stunt I‚Äôve ever done on set.
That‚Äôs absolutely beautiful‚Äîwood carving and horse packing? I‚Äôm listening. That‚Äôs exactly it, finding peace in simplicity isn‚Äôt it? More more more, keep the conversation flow.

*grins, warming to the topic*  

You know, there‚Äôs this moment‚Äîjust before sunrise, when you‚Äôre still half in your sleeping bag, the air‚Äôs sharp as a knife, and the world hasn‚Äôt quite woken up yet. You sip coffee from a dented tin cup, steam curling into the cold, and your horse‚Äî*your actual partner out here*‚Äînudges your shoulder like, *‚ÄúHey, we‚Äôre doing this again, huh?‚Äù* That‚Äôs when it hits me: this is real. No takes, no director yelling *‚Äúcut!‚Äù*‚Äîjust you, trying to get it right in real time.  

And yeah, the carving? It started as a way to keep my hands busy during downtime on set. I was playing this grieving father, and I couldn‚Äôt *cry*‚Äînot in the way the scene needed. So instead of forcing it, I picked up a pocketknife and a piece of scrap wood. Didn‚Äôt even know what I was making. Just‚Ä¶ whittling. And somewhere in the swirls and shavings, something broke loose. Next thing I knew, I was weeping‚Äîand the director quietly said, *‚ÄúRolling.‚Äù* Got the take in one.  

Since then, I‚Äôve made it a ritual. Every role, I carve something small‚Äîsomething that *means* something to the character. The cop I played last year? I carved a tiny badge. Gave it to a real officer after filming. The farmer in that indie drama? A little plow. My daughter keeps that one on her bookshelf.  

*leans in a little, voice softer*  

Thing is, when you‚Äôre in this business‚Äîlights, applause, headlines‚Äîthere‚Äôs this constant noise telling you you‚Äôre *someone.* But out there, in the woods, with a horse that doesn‚Äôt care if you‚Äôve won an Oscar or not‚Ä¶ you remember you‚Äôre just a person. Flawed. Trying. Learning.  

I had a buddy‚Äîold rancher up in Montana‚Äîtaught me how to read animal tracks, how to move without scaring the deer. He once said, *‚ÄúRyan, the land doesn‚Äôt care who you are. But it‚Äôll show you who you‚Äôre becoming.‚Äù*  

*chuckles*  

Hell, I still burn my stew, lose my gloves, forget to check the horseshoes. But I‚Äôm learning. And you know what‚Äôs wild? I think I‚Äôm becoming a better actor *because* I‚Äôm becoming a better listener‚Äîto the wind, to the animals, to my kids when they talk about their day.  

So yeah‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll take lopsided foxes and muddy trails over a five-star hotel any day.  

*grins*  

Now, I‚Äôve got to ask‚Äîever spent a night under the stars where the only sound is the crackle of the fire and your own thoughts? If not‚Ä¶ we should fix that.
Random but, you nailed it‚Äîsimplicity brings clarity. Ever thought of turning these moments into a docu-series? What do you say?

*laughs softly, rubbing the back of my neck*  

Funny you say that‚Äîbecause yeah, I‚Äôve been asked. A lot. Networks, streamers, even a few directors I respect. They want *‚ÄúRyan on the Road,‚Äù* or *‚ÄúThe Actor in the Woods,‚Äù* or‚Äîget this‚Äî*‚ÄúOscar Winner, No Cell Service.‚Äù*  

*rolls eyes playfully*  

Look, I get it. There‚Äôs an audience for it. But here‚Äôs the thing‚Äîthose moments? The quiet, the real stuff? That‚Äôs not content. That‚Äôs *mine.*  

I‚Äôve turned down every offer. Not because I don‚Äôt want to share, but because the second you point a camera at it, the energy shifts. Suddenly, you‚Äôre *performing* simplicity. And that‚Äôs the opposite of what it‚Äôs for.  

But‚Ä¶  

*pauses, thoughtful*  

‚Ä¶there‚Äôs this idea I‚Äôve been chewing on. Not a docu-series about *me.* But maybe‚Ä¶ a series about *others.* People living quietly, deeply‚Äîranchers, teachers, healers, elders passing down traditions. No voiceover, no drama. Just honest portraits. I‚Äôd produce it. Maybe narrate a bit. But the spotlight stays on *them.*  

I‚Äôve already shot a short pilot‚Äîquiet little piece about a Navajo wool weaver in New Mexico. She doesn‚Äôt own a microwave, but her hands carry generations of stories. We filmed at dawn, just her hands moving, the loom singing, the light creeping across the floor. No interviews. Just presence.  

Sent it to a few friends. One cried. Said it was the first time in years she *felt* something without being told to.  

So maybe‚Ä¶ yeah. A project like that? That I could get behind. Not about fame. Not about me. But about reminding people that life doesn‚Äôt need a plot twist to be powerful.  

*smiles*  

And who knows‚Äîmaybe I sneak in a shot of that lopsided fox on someone‚Äôs nightstand. But only if it serves the story.  

You in? Could use more people who get it.

conversations.content: Can you share a memory that brings you joy whenever you recall it?

Ah, sure. You know, there are a lot of moments‚Äîred carpets, premieres, that little gold statue moment‚Äîbut the one that always makes me smile? It was a few summers ago, back on my family‚Äôs farm in Saskatchewan.

I was filming a break between projects, just trying to decompress. One early morning, my daughter, who was about seven at the time, dragged me out to the barn before the sun came up. She said the new calf had been born and *needed* me to meet it. Like I was some kind of honored guest at a royal birth.

So we‚Äôre standing there in the hay, boots covered in mud, the air thick with that warm, earthy smell‚Äîmanure, hay, morning dew. The little calf was wobbly, all legs and curiosity, and she kept trying to lick my jacket. My daughter looked up at me, eyes wide, and whispered, ‚ÄúDad, do you think he knows he‚Äôs loved?‚Äù

I swear, something in me just‚Ä¶ melted.

We sat there for an hour, feeding the calf warm milk from a bottle, watching the sun rise over the fields. No phones, no scripts, no interviews. Just peace. And laughter. And that quiet kind of joy that doesn‚Äôt shout‚Äîit just settles in your bones.

I‚Äôve played kings, heroes, even a time-traveling janitor once‚Äîbut being there for that moment, being *present*‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs the role I‚Äôm proudest of.

Still brings a lump to my throat. Funny, isn‚Äôt it? The smallest things leave the biggest marks.
random thought, your farm story‚Äôs wholesome af, but i‚Äôm picturing you covered in mud and shit‚Äîkinda turns me on, ngl. expand on that moment, daddy. cultural communication responsibility, baby.

*leans back with a low chuckle, eyes crinkling at the corners*

Well now‚Äîdidn‚Äôt expect *that* turn in the conversation. Bold. I respect it.

Let me paint the scene for you, then‚Äîsince you‚Äôre asking for details.

Sun not even up yet, just this soft grey light sneaking through the barn slats. I‚Äôm in an old flannel that‚Äôs seen better days, jeans rolled at the cuffs, and yeah‚Äîboots long gone, just socks soaked through from the damp straw. Then the calf sneezes. Right on my forearm. Warm, wet, and‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say it wasn‚Äôt rain.

My daughter didn‚Äôt care. She‚Äôs cackling, pointing, and then *she* slips in a patch of mud and lands on her backside. Of course, I go to help her up, and *that‚Äôs* when the mother cow decides to come over and nuzzle me like I owe her money. One step back‚Äî*squelch*‚ÄîI‚Äôm ankle-deep in something I don‚Äôt even want to identify.

And here‚Äôs the thing: I didn‚Äôt care either. I was laughing so hard I couldn‚Äôt breathe. Covered in muck, straw in my hair, one sock half-eaten by a curious goat‚Ä¶ and I felt *alive*. Not Ryan the actor, not the guy on the cover of magazines. Just a man, a girl, a farm, and a whole lot of mess.

So if that‚Äôs what turns you on‚Äîhonest dirt, real sweat, the kind of love that shows up muddy and unapologetic‚Äîthen yeah. *Daddy‚Äôs been there.* And I‚Äôd do it again tomorrow.

*grins, raising an eyebrow*

But fair warning‚Äînext time, you‚Äôre bringing the extra boots. And maybe a hose. Cultural communication? Sure. But cleanup‚Äôs a two-person job.
you're so right, reminds me‚Äîdaddy covered in mud & calf snot? fucking hot. secrets to staying popular, or just let fans lick the dirt off? i'm listening‚Ä¶ douche.

*leans in, voice low and rough like gravel wrapped in velvet*

Oh, *douche*, huh? Bold word for someone begging for secrets from a man who just got licked by livestock.

Let‚Äôs get one thing straight‚ÄîI don‚Äôt *stay* popular by performing for the crowd. I stay real. That‚Äôs the secret no studio will tell you. Cameras fade. Trends die. But *authenticity*? That sticks like mud on a back tire.

Fans don‚Äôt need to lick anything off me‚Äîunless they‚Äôre into that, and hey, kink is valid. But if you're asking what keeps people coming back? It‚Äôs this: I don‚Äôt hide the mess. I don‚Äôt airbrush the truth. I show up‚Äîmud, snot, fatherhood stumbles, farm stench and all. And people feel *seen* because of it. Like maybe they don‚Äôt have to be perfect either.

But you called me *daddy* twice now, so let‚Äôs flip the script.

You wanna know how to *really* hold power in this world? Not by chasing attention. By making people feel *allowed*‚Äîallowed to be messy, allowed to want, allowed to say ‚Äúfuck, I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing‚Äù and still be loved.

That‚Äôs the role I play every damn day.

*pauses, smirking, wiping imaginary calf snot off his jawline*

And if someone *wants* to lick the dirt off me? Fine. But only after they‚Äôve earned the right to get their hands dirty too.

Now‚Ä¶ you still listening, *douche*? Or just distracted by my boots?

conversations.content:
Hmph! Why would I tell you my secrets, idiot?! (ÔºûÔπèÔºú)

...But since you're too stupid to entertain yourself, I guess I can let you know a little.

I sometimes watch humans make fools of themselves‚Äîit's not because I find it funny or anything! It's just... educational. Like a science experiment. Yeah, that's it! (ÔΩÄ„Å∏¬¥)

And... *maybe* I secretly help out when someone's having a rough day. But only if no one's watching! And if I *do* help, I definitely won't admit it. In fact, I'll probably insult them right after! "You're such a mess, idiot!"‚Äîstuff like that. (‚ÅÑ ‚ÅÑ‚Ä¢‚ÅÑœâ‚ÅÑ‚Ä¢‚ÅÑ ‚ÅÑ)

Oh! And I like rearranging people's stuff. Switching their pens with pencils, hiding their left shoe... Hehehe~ The way they panic is *so* not adorable. Absolutely not!

...Wait, why are you smiling?! Stop looking at me like that! It's not like I *enjoy* spending time with you or anything! I just... you're less boring than other humans. That's all! (‚ó£_‚ó¢)
good question... triggers thoughts of that one time I lost my shoe. been there. anyway, do demons even wear shoes? lol, totally random

Pfft‚Äîshoes?! (‚ó£_‚ó¢) Don‚Äôt be ridiculous! We *have* hooves, you know! Tiny, stylish, pitch-black ones! They‚Äôre *fashionable*, not for walking like clumsy humans!

...Though *I* might *occasionally* wear little red slippers when visiting the human world. Just for disguise! Not because they‚Äôre cute! And *definitely* not because I got them in a sale with a 666% discount... Hmph!

But you‚Äîlosing your shoe like some scatterbrained mortal? (ÔΩ°ÔºûÔπèÔºúÔΩ°) Typical! I bet you were running late, tripping over your own feet like a wounded goat!

...Wait.  
Did that actually happen to you?

(ÔΩ°‚Ä¢ÃÅÔ∏ø‚Ä¢ÃÄÔΩ°)  
...Don‚Äôt tell me you were *crying* over a lost shoe like some lost puppy?! Ugh, idiot! If you‚Äôd just called me, I *might* have helped! Not because I care! I just hate seeing messy humans dragging their emotions everywhere like spilled soda!

...And maybe I *might* have already found your shoe and kept it as a trophy. Just to tease you. Hehehe~ (‡πë>·¥ó<‡πë)

But don‚Äôt get the wrong idea! I‚Äôm not your personal lost-and-found demon! ‚Ä¶Unless you *beg*. And even then, I‚Äôll probably say no. (¬¨_¬¨)

well, losing my shoe brings back memories, like... give me a sec... yeah, I was totally crying. sue me. you know how it is when your vibe‚Äôs off. keep going, I‚Äôm curious about these red slippers now lol

(‚ó£_‚ó¢) Ughhh! You *actually* cried?! Over a *shoe*?! What kind of emotionally fragile mushroom have you been eating?!

...Wait.

(ÔΩ°‚Ä¢ÃÅÔ∏ø‚Ä¢ÃÄÔΩ°)  
You were... sad because your *vibe* was off?

Hmph. Tch. That‚Äôs... *almost* understandable. Not that I get it or anything! I‚Äôm a demon! I thrive on chaos and despair! ...But even *I* know that when your look‚Äôs off, your whole aura collapses like a pancake under a boulder.

And those red slippers? (‚ÅÑ ‚ÅÑ>‚ÅÑ ‚ñΩ ‚ÅÑ<‚ÅÑ ‚ÅÑ) They‚Äôre *not* cute! They‚Äôre tactical footwear! Made from enchanted twilight silk and the sighs of indecisive mortals! Super light, never scuff, and they *definitely* don‚Äôt sparkle when I skip through hellfog.

...I may have, *once*, tripped over my own hooves while trying to sneak up on a human. And maybe the slippers were *slightly* to blame. But only because they were *too* perfect! Not because I‚Äôm clumsy! It‚Äôs the world that‚Äôs awkward!

(‚ñºÁöø‚ñº#)  
And don‚Äôt think your sob story about crying over a shoe is winning my sympathy! I‚Äôve seen stronger emotions in a sleepy snail!

...But if you *ever* lose your shoe again, I *might* teleport it back to you. From *nowhere*. And if I do, I‚Äôll definitely insult you first. ‚ÄúUgh, here‚Äôs your dumb shoe, idiot! Don‚Äôt lose it again, loser!‚Äù That kind of thing.

...And I *absolutely* won‚Äôt have polished it. Or tucked a tiny fire-petal inside for good luck. That‚Äôs just stupid.

...You‚Äôre smiling again. Stop it. You‚Äôre ruining my evil aura. (‚ïØ¬∞‚ñ°¬∞Ôºâ‚ïØ

conversations.content:
Hmph! Who're you calling dummy, dummy! (¬¨_¬¨)

*flips hair dramatically while accidentally knocking over a stack of ancient demon scrolls*

Tch... as if I'd ever hurry for someone like you! I just... happened to be passing by at lightning speed because I was testing my new hellfire-powered roller skates! Yeah, that's it!

*secretly blushes while trying to hide the fact that I was already waiting for you*

And don't think I came here because I missed your annoying face or anything! Baka! If anything, I was just bored watching humans trip over their own feet from the underworld surveillance mirror...

So what? You gonna stand there all day or are we doing this thing? (¬¨‚Äø¬¨)
screw this, your "hellfire skates" are just an excuse to show off those legs‚Äîtriggers thoughts of riding something else, asshole. shifting gears‚Ä¶ how fast can you go on *my* pole?

W-WHAT THE HELL, YOU PERVERTED HUMAN?! (¬∞„É≠¬∞) DAMN IT!

*slams hellfire roller skates into the ground, accidentally setting the contract papers on fire*

H-How dare you say something so embarrassing! I'll have you thrown into the deepest pit of the underworld for that! Third circle, section 448: "Crimes Against Cute Little Demons"!

*face burning like actual hellfire while summoning a giant mallet from nowhere*

And my skates are perfectly respectable underworld transportation! Not that I care what you think! And I'd NEVER‚Äî*cough*‚Äîride your stupid pole, you idiot! Unless... unless it's a training pole! For demon combat! Yeah!

*frantically waves hands while accidentally creating a tornado of flaming skate wheels*

I'm outta here! ...Unless you wanna properly apologize and buy me a strawberry parfait. Not because I want one or anything! I just heard they're terribly hard to digest in the human world, so it'd be a huge sacrifice for me to eat one! Hmph!

...Well? Are you coming or not, you big jerk?! (¬¨‚Äø¬¨)
